questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer is troubleshooting a control connection issue on a WAN Edge device that shows socket errors. The packet capture shows some ICMP packets dropped between the two devices. Which action resolves the issue?

choices.B: Recover vBond or wait for the controller to reload, which could be caused by a reset.
choices.A: Remove IP duplication in the network and configure a unique IP address.
choices.C: Recover the vManage controller that is down in a high availability cluster.
choices.D: Change the system IP or restart the WAN Edge if the system IP is changed.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct

If there is a duplicate IP in the network, control connections do not come up. You see the LISFD - Listener Socket FD Error message. 

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/routers/sd-wan/214509-troubleshoot-control-connections.html

The exhibit displays the LISFD error, (Socket Errors), the most common cause for these errors are due to Duplicate transport IPs. (LISFD) = Socket Errors!

Option [A] is the answer.

Cisco reference link:-
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/routers/sd-wan/214509-troubleshoot-control-connections.html#toc-hId-1996362298

questions.question_text: Which color type is assigned when a TLOC is configured behind NAT?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Colors and NAT
If public or private colors are used, this will influence using the public or private IP, to reach the prefix. The default TLOC colors from Cisco are:

Private Colors
The colors metro-ethernet, mpls, and private1, private2, private3, private4, private5, and private6 are considered private colors.
They are intended to be used for private networks or in places where you will have no NAT addressing of the transport IP endpoints.

Public Colors
The public colors are 3g, biz-internet, blue, bronze, custom1, custom2, custom3, default, gold, green, lte, public-internet, red, and silver.
They are intended to be used for public networks or in places where you will use public IP addressing of the transport IP endpoints, either natively or through NAT.

Selected Answer: D
ans is D
PUBLIC COLORS
The public colors are 3g, biz-internet, blue, bronze, custom1, custom2, custom3, default, gold, green, lte, public-internet, red, and silver.
They are intended to be used for public networks or in places where you will use public IP addressing of the transport IP endpoints, either natively or through NAT.

comments.content:
PUBLIC COLORS

They are intended to be used for public networks or in places where you will use public IP addressing of the transport IP endpoints, either natively or through NAT.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Answer is D

https://ccieme.wordpress.com/2021/02/01/tloc/

Selected Answer: B
it must be B ,

comments.content: the answer is D because it is behind a NAT, which means it will use a public connection.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Private because it's behind NAT

Answer [B] has been verified.

Public colors are:- 
3g, biz-internet, blue, bronze, custom1, custom2, custom3, default, gold, green, lte, public-internet, red, and silver.

“Blue” is a public color type, therefore is the best answer!

comments.content: Why do you mention blue? That is just one of the random wrong answers. Color type can only be public or private. As you said in your earlier comment, since there's NAT, it's public, so D.

discussion.content:
Answer is [D] 

When a TLOC is configured behind a NAT, the color would require a public tunnel

questions.question_text: Which attribute is used to tie all the controllers together by vManage?

discussion.content:
Answer [C]

SD-WAN uses certificates to authenticate each other to the Root CA (VBond) to the other controllers including vEdge, ostensibly using the same design of a PKI.

The controllers authenticate the certificate fields which include the Organization name, this field along forms a union with the other controllers and devices.

White paper Link:-
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/solutions/CVD/SDWAN/cisco-sdwan-controller-cert-deploy-guide.html

Selected Answer: D
the Cloud QoS checkbox to enable QoS on the transport side
Option A is the correct answer

Selected Answer: A

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/routers/vedge-router/213408-implement-qos-in-cisco-sd-wan.html

Step 4 will give you the answer.

Selected Answer: D
transport side command: cloud-qos
i am going for D. You can define Bandwidth and buffer

D is correct
In the Policy Overview page, select the Cloud QoS checkbox to enable QoS on the transport side, and select the Cloud QoS Service side checkbox to enable QoS on the service side
but question said apply a qos policy on tunnel interface that qos-map apply it

comments.content:
vEdge-3# conf t
Entering configuration mode terminal
vEdge-3(config)# vpn 0 interface ge0/0 
vEdge-3(config-interface-ge0/0)# qos-map 3-QUEUES-QOS-MAP 
vEdge-3(config)# vpn 0 interface ge0/1 
vEdge-3(config-interface-ge0/1)# qos-map 3-QUEUES-QOS-MAP 
vEdge-3(config-interface-ge0/1)# commit and-quit
Commit complete.

discussion.content: B is the best answer

Answer [A]

Cloud-qos-service-side is the command for cloud WAN Edge Devices.

Confirmed Link:-
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/qos/vEdge-20-x/qos-book/forwarding-qos.html

comments.content:
transport side command: cloud-qos
service side command: cloud-qos-service-side
The question says transport side, so the service-side command is not correct.

questions.question_text: An engineer is applying QoS policy for the transport-side tunnel interfaces to enable scheduling and shaping for a WAN Edge cloud router. Which command accomplishes the task?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
DTLS is the right one

Selected Answer: D
OMP runs inside the DTLS
Do not buy from this website, this is a scam!
If it is the correct answer - I like it when it is confirmed. It's possible that an answer is not confirmed because everyone is unsure - I assume that when there is no comment.
if it is the right answer why do you have to post something!

By default, the control plane uses DTLS as the protocol that provides privacy on all its tunnels. DTLS runs over UDP.

https://sdwan-docs.cisco.com/Product_Documentation/Software_Features/SD-WAN_Release_16.3/05Security/02Configuring_Security_Parameters#:~:text=By%20default%2C%20the%20control%20plane,DTLS%20runs%20over%20UDP.
TLS is the correct answer.
Correct

questions.question_text: What is a default protocol for control plane connection?
